{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3372350,"name":"Gal","username":"GalDotan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galdotan/{size}/201749_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T16:55:46.992Z","cooked":"

What is your most useful sensors to control a system? What would you recommend?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T16:55:46.992Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":237,"reads":1056,"readers_count":1055,"score":1406.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"Gal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60986,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5951 Software and electrical lead"},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/1","custom_user_title":"5951 Software and electrical lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3372399,"name":"jweston","username":"jweston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jweston/{size}/8210_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T17:15:58.822Z","cooked":"

Highly accurate and reliable encoders such as the REV through bore encoder. CTR-E magnet encoders are excellent too but it’s important to make sure your magnet alignment/spacing and wiring are solid.

Sensitive gyro such as the Kauai Labs navX2. I haven’t used the CTR-E Pigeon but I’ve heard they’re fantastic too.

Vision camera; A lot of variation on these. A lot depends on what you’re trying to do with them (driver camera, AprilTag detection, object detection, etc.). For detection, finding the best high contrast/fewest pixels that you can get away with helps with faster vision processing.

Beam break sensors; I don’t really have a favorite product. It depends on the application since power and range vary.

Limit switches; When using physical contact limit switches, please, please, please do not place these where they can be smashed. They are emergency shut offs. Better yet, use a magnetic limit switch.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T17:15:58.822Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":1048,"readers_count":1047,"score":394.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"jweston","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":10}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372426,"name":"Gal","username":"GalDotan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galdotan/{size}/201749_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T17:30:45.891Z","cooked":"

Checkout the LaserCAN from Grapple robotics.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T17:34:05.571Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":923,"readers_count":922,"score":184.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"Lauchlin","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60986,"username":"GalDotan","name":"Gal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galdotan/{size}/201749_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":29278,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372484,"name":"jweston","username":"jweston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jweston/{size}/8210_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T18:15:44.191Z","cooked":"
GalDotan:

Have you ever used range sensors? Maby to find the travel of an elevator or a system

I have. Range sensors can be a little tricky but they exist for a reason. Range sensors have a limit to their resolution. That is, they are limited in terms of their accuracy (to the nearest 1cm or 1mm etc), their far distance limit, and their near distance limit.

You need to be very careful with ultrasonics. You need to know what the beam pattern (how wide the the echo signal is) and make sure nothing is going to interfere with it. There are ways to synchronize multiple ultrasonics on your robot so they don’t interfere with each other too. But all of this takes proper planning and implementation.

There are also differences in ultrasonics in how signal is indicated. Some may be wired to indicate with voltage (not my favorite; need very stable electrical power/signal for this). Some may output digitally.

IR range sensors, like the REV 2m Distance Sensor, are more focused than ultrasonics but the signal may not reflect off of certain materials consistently like clear polycarbonate (i.e. not a good combo).

LIDAR is probably the best solution for range sensing but they tend to be more expensive. I haven’t had the opportunity to use LIDAR, though.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T18:17:22.129Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":21,"reads":880,"readers_count":879,"score":281.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"jweston","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25112,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372498,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T18:31:38.554Z","cooked":"

I’m a huge fan of two-sided visible light beam-break sensors like this one for detecting game piece locations in a robot.

We’ve had all kinds of problems with lots of different reflective-type sensors, particularly IR-based ones, giving false-positives, false-negatives, and pretty much every weird behavior in-between. The only downside is that at $66 a set, they’re quite a bit more expensive, but you can’t beat the reliability. We use these via Analog inputs, but I’m pretty sure if you add a certain resistor to them they can be used as DIO inputs too.

I hope at some point someone develops a cheaper option, maybe even something using low-power lasers for better precision.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T18:33:12.722Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":9,"reads":770,"readers_count":769,"score":219.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.automationdirect.com/adc/shopping/catalog/sensors_-z-_encoders/photoelectric_sensors/general_purpose_photoelectric_sensors/qmrhd-0n-0a","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":231}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372504,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T18:39:15.465Z","cooked":"

For ranging/beam break style sensors for game piece detection within a robot, we used the LaserCAN from Grapple on our robot this year. Setting their CAN id’s was a little troublesome (the grapplehook client had semi-regular issues detecting them on the network), once they were “set” though, we didn’t have to worry about them again for the entire season. They were reliable and effective, I’ll happily use them again moving forward.

With regards to an accurate gyro/IMU, we’ve had issues over the years with the navX2. Things like comms issues with the device to relatively bad drift (“bad” in respect to using it for field relative swerve drive) despite frequent attempts to calibrate. This year we switched to Pigeon 2.0 and haven’t looked back since. We’ve seen minimal drift and the device seems to “just work”.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T18:39:29.779Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":733,"readers_count":732,"score":186.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/7","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372513,"name":"Roman A.","username":"RomanTechPlus","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/romantechplus/{size}/214929_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T18:47:51.855Z","cooked":"

A high quality, low latency, industrial beambreak. The ones we use are shock resistant and IP68 with (iirc) 200ns response time. They are great for any situation where you just need to reliably and quickly know you have something. Through-beam is best in general.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T18:47:59.883Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":674,"readers_count":673,"score":144.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"Roman A.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53160,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5104 BreakerBots | Software and Additive Mfg. This season we used cheap beam breakers (you can find them at Amazon for 5$) and we didn’t have a single problem with them. Are the more expensive ones justified the cost?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T19:16:26.718Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":639,"readers_count":638,"score":147.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"Gal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60986,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5951 Software and electrical lead"},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/9","custom_user_title":"5951 Software and electrical lead","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372591,"name":"John Fogarty","username":"JohnFogarty","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/johnfogarty/{size}/267052_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T19:28:26.788Z","cooked":"

Some of the more expensive ones (Banner) are adjustable/tunable if you have have issues with lighting.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T19:28:26.788Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":630,"readers_count":629,"score":146.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60986,"username":"GalDotan","name":"Gal","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/galdotan/{size}/201749_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372615,"name":"zeequeue","username":"zeequeue","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zeequeue/{size}/11778_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T19:42:07.375Z","cooked":"

We used these digital distance sensors (Pololu Digital Distance Sensors) in lieu of beam breaks this year and they worked really well (especially since they were mounted in a weird spot on our intake that would have required some interesting beam break alignment/positioning)

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T19:42:07.375Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":611,"readers_count":610,"score":227.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"zeequeue","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.pololu.com/category/283/pololu-digital-distance-sensors","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pololu Digital Distance Sensors","clicks":69}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27102,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC #354 Coach | WPILib Developer - Romi/XRP"},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/11","custom_user_title":"FRC #354 Coach | WPILib Developer - Romi/XRP","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372628,"name":"H","username":"AluminumMagikarp","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/e9a140/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T19:56:23.090Z","cooked":"
JohnFogarty:

adjustable/tunable if you have have issues with lighting.

We have considerable issues with this as our practice area is outside (well, at least our full-scale one). Do these or other sensors work in direct sunlight?

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-24T19:56:23.090Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":579,"readers_count":578,"score":155.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"H","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60963,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2637 Strategy/Drive Mentor | 8891 Controls Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/12","custom_user_title":"2637 Strategy/Drive Mentor | 8891 Controls Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3372719,"name":"Dkt01","username":"Dkt01","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkt01/{size}/4603_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-24T21:28:27.627Z","cooked":"

I was actually just talking to another mentor on my team and we’ve semi-intentionally down-selected to a very small number of sensors:

  • CTRE CANCoders - Been rock-solid for us for swerve and absolute position implement applications. Added benefit of fused CANCoder control with PhoenixPro, which I highly recommend based on our experience this past season.
  • Playing With Fusion CAN Time of Flight - Since 2020, these have been our go-to for game piece position sensing. Having CAN capability makes our wiring cleaner and the distance readings are more reliable than ultrasonic sensors. They do have less reliable distance measurement at very close distances, so sometimes we use the basic IR sensor below instead.
  • E18-D80NK-N IR proximity sensors - Really, any similar sensor would work, but the panel-mount form factor and general robustness of these sensors has been great for us. We used two of these this year since they are great for close-range note detection and can be wired into a limit switch input of a motor controller for fast response (no misfires during intake)
  • Pigeon 2 IMU - We were previously an Analog Devices IMU team because the raw specs of that IMU are so impressive, but since switching to the Pigeon 2 in 2021, we’ve had far better robot yaw estimates due to the fantastic drift compensation. Also CAN (and CAN FD) is sweet. Higher update frequencies enabled us to have more accurate odometry for autonomous than we thought we’d be able to with non-CANFD devices.
  • Limelight 3G - Or 3, or the latest version. The integrated software on the LimeLight platform has enabled our team to accomplish far more vision capability in far less time than any other approach we’ve tried. They’re expensive, but we don’t waste as much time going this route.

Common theme: CAN and ethernet are great, let’s do more of that. Contactless detection is our preference to physical switches, but we do occasionally have a microswitch somewhere for homing or as a physical limit switch. Value your time. Sometimes there may be another solution that’s cheaper, but if you spend all season trying to make it work, maybe the cost is worth it. Re-using components helps amortize costs of expensive parts over multiple seasons.

But sometimes you’ll need a unique sensor for a unique challenge. We used a Playing With Fusion color sensor in 2020 for the control panel, for example. An example of a sensor we’ve phased out is string potentiometers (yo-yo’s) in favor of absolute encoders for robustness throughout competition. Turns out you can get longer absolute positining ranges with gear boxes .

jweston:

Highly accurate and reliable encoders such as the REV through bore encoder

You find these reliable? I’ve heard many complaints about how often they break or the JST-PH connectors come out, which has been my experience with them the last few years too.

My team also really likes the LaserCAN from Grapple Robotics. It is a really nice, CAN-enabled, rangefinder device that we use for our elevator position.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":54,"updated_at":"2024-04-26T18:30:42.618Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":373,"readers_count":372,"score":99.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":464358,"topic_slug":"useful-must-have-sensors","display_username":"Zach","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52196,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build Lead (COO)"},"post_url":"/t/useful-must-have-sensors/464358/18","custom_user_title":"Build Lead (COO)","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3374792,"name":"jweston","username":"jweston","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jweston/{size}/8210_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-26T21:04:17.173Z","cooked":"

In my experience, they have been very reliable, especially for FTC odometry with the JST-PH 4-pin cables.

In FRC, my experience has been to wire the through bore encoders to the roboRIO with the quadrature output cable(s).

The REV NEO wiring is another story. That’s dodgy. I’ve had success with re-crimping those, though.
